job_title: Visiting Research Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: This was absolutely a great place to work. The professional development opportunities were amazing.
cons: No cons truly. This place was a joy.

job_title: Graduate Lab Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Flexible work schedule for my position in this lab
cons: No benefits or opportunity to increase wage

review_title: Everything you hate about working for the state.
pros: There's a lot of flexibility here. The benefits are very good and we get a lot of vacation/sick time--so much to be the envy of others. As a state employer, employee rights, discrimination, harassment are all taken seriously.
cons: The bad news is that the departments have more of an adversarial feel rather than a working together toward a common goal. Getting technological improvements moves very slowly and process protocols are ridiculously complicated. There tends to be a lot of political infighting. Also, it is really difficult to get a raise here beyond a few cost-of-living increases. Upward mobility is difficult--you basically have to move out of your department into a completely different job in order to move up.

pros: Benefits, guaranteed pay increase for nurses every year
cons: parking fee is deducted with every paycheck

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) I in Chicago, IL
pros: The education benefits are great.
cons: Everything else. Management & leadership have lost their way. Health benefits are expensive. Pension is crappy. Work environment is toxic. Pay is not good

pros: Great for full-time students who are looking for a job during the school year.
cons: Staff is not always accommodating during finals season

pros: Good workplace culture, co-workers are helpful and collaborative. Good bosses. Decent pay, and excellent State benefits. 25 paid vacation days per year, not including holidays and gift days. Reduced rate on gym membership.
cons: Have to work onsite, parking is not included. Annual raises cap out at 2.5%, but inflation has been like 7%, so you basically lose money by working here. Other places have way better annual raises.

pros: Union contracts, scheduled raises, 6 week paid maternity leave and INA contract says job is saved for 6 months
cons: old building, pay for parking

pros: benefits including health are great

review_title: A massive hospital system that can be dangerously dysfunctional on a high-acuity unit

pros: They have very good benefits.
cons: Any HR interaction is dreadfully long; it took 5 and a half months from the time of applying to my start date. I applied for an promotion and it has now been 6 months and they have said that I am the candidate but have done nothing to actually increase my salary and change my job title.

pros: great learning environment, competitive pay, careers advancement

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: There are no pros to write here.

Pay was extremely low
I would avoid working in the center for clinical and transnational science (CCTS). 2 women in particular had some real issues going on at this unit and loved drama.

review_title: Great company if you work in a functional department!
pros:
Good benefits. You get awesome vacation days. 
Job security. You'll almost always have a job.
Great experience. You can work for various departments and gain experience if you don't like to sit tight more than 5 years.
cons:
Horrible interdepartmental communication sometimes
Can be stressful if you work in a disorganized department

job_title: Clinical Nurse I in Chicago, IL
pros: My team works well together
cons: Administration and staff are pitted against each other.

pros: Great opportunity to advance at the hospital

job_title: Food Service Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits for FT employees
cons: They use a system called “extra help” to hire people in without offering any benefits for 900 hours of employment, which can also be granted extensions. I was promised a FT position and am now up to 1300 hours of “extra help”, constantly stuck covering the other 3 managers who get to use benefit time, and am applying for jobs elsewhere.

pros: Salary compensation is above average. Vacation time is excellent.
cons: Executive leadership needs a clean sweep. There is no vision, strategy, and leaders are completely disconnected from the patients and workforce.

cons: Nursing Leadership is toxic, Nursing staff is lazy and not professional, unionized hospital. would not work here again.

pros: Fantastic benefits package. Lots of days off.

pros: Good benefits, tuition reimbursement good.
cons: Organization culture is negative, hostile and high stress, High turnovers, dissatisfaction, weakness and tension. Employees have no respect each other or their superiors. No accountability for getting things done in any department. No vision or drive.. Departments have excuses for completing projects that has to be done.  Employees are not open to managerial changes. Employees are intimidated and even terrified of the thought of change.. Organization do not value employees, no raises or incentive. Hard to fire bad employees, loud, rude, disrespectful. Lacking good customer service and bed side manner skills. Organization is struck, no vision or structural of how to get there.  State budget seem to always effect pay raises.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: wonderful place to work by far
cons: none, nothing, none at all, no cons., nope

pros: Good benefits with adequate health coverage
cons: Salary less than ideal with hours given

pros: Academic setting, good docs, interesting residents, challenging patients, union contract, great benefits and pay
cons: Culture discourages employees from striving for better  performance, management tries to find loopholes in contract instead of abiding by it,  hires from outside rather then move from within for cheaper labor and less benefits, hard for nurses to change units to enhance their profession and mgmt knows the nurse usually won't leave the "u" after passing probation so the nurse stagnates and just ""does the job" because his/her efforts are not rewarded.  He/she is stuck where they are.    This is a change from the past when current nurses were valued and given opportunities to grow by changing units and often working several in their career.  Not the place I first worked.  Insurance decent but slow paying (11 months after service) so be prepared to pay at the visit, pay in a few weeks or go to collections and get your credit damaged.

review_title: Decent place to work but room for improvement
pros: Benefits and vacation time are generous.  For the most part management is flexible and allows you to work independently.  If you are academic staff, they are flexible about your work schedule.  There is a tuition waiver, and room for advancement. If you leave and decide to come back, managment tries to be accommodating.  Most of the staff is friendly, open to going above and beyond the call of duty to help other team members and patients.
cons: Your salary increases are minimal.  If you do have to use a time clock, there is very little flexibility in your schedule and you get reprimanded for clocking in early, late, and managers will usually not approve overtime pay.

review_title: Don't do more than your share
pros: Great benefits in pay, health, retirement, easy location, tuition reimbursement, annual raises based on union membership.
cons: Ridiculous amount of work. There are more work than anyone can personally accomplish. It will overwhelm you. The game plan is to do the least amount of work possible, just enough to keep your job, and then go home at exactly when you need to. Volunteering for more work will not help you gain pay or promotion. If you are looking for a place to dedicate to, this is definitely not the place. If you need something done, you will need to talk to multiple departments and it will take forever to complete.

pros: You have the freedom to be creative and come up with solutions. It's a big organization for room to grow. Benefits are good.
cons: There is a LOT to improve in as an organization. If not a hourly worker your work/life can be hard to balance- so be strong with ensuring you make your life a priority. Top level management is always changing. Its impossible to fire anyone... therefore those lazy coworkers will always be there!

review_title: The Infection Control Department is Fantastic
job_title: Lead Contact Tracer in Chicago, IL
pros: Decent leadership who are present, helpful, and willing to listen and provide guidance as needed. Plenty of room for growth, especially in a pandemic. Competitive salary and benefits. Honest, diligent work is acknowledged and rewarded.
cons: The cafeteria feels like a rip-off. They used to include chips with a sandwich, but they discontinued that to save money (way before pandemic started). Parking lottery could improve. Salaried folks may have long hours some weeks, depending on the work load.

pros: Ability to serve patients who have very limited access to medical care.  Many bi-lingual Spanish speaking staff members.  Many efforts have been made to improve the quality of service and some building renovations.
cons: Employee suggestions for improvement can be dismissed, or met with opposition.  Employee can be singled out and be treated differently for making a suggestion or bringing a specific occurrence to light.

job_title: IT Technical Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: Management listens to what you have to say and in turn give a great deal of clarity on the direction of the organization and what that in turn means to you. The compensation is good especially when factoring in large amount of paid time off and virtually no expectation to work from home.
cons: Due to the unique way the University runs the hospital and the medical colleges, politics can get in the way of progress. Most non-management employees in the Information Services department recently became part of the SEIU union, this is unconventional and not necessarily a Con but it should be mentioned.

pros: Large academic medical center, with a lot of really bright minds around.  Offer EMTs more independence than a lot of other hospitals
cons: It is a really disorganized, state funded hospital.  Definitely could use more structure in the ED, controlled chaos is putting it lightly.  EMTs are required to do far to much and staffed far too lightly.

review_title: Good working environment and intelligent faculty
pros: This is a great place to work if you are higher up in management. There is a good oppertunity to grow. Compensation could be better and facilities could be better.
cons: It takes alot of time to get paperwork and payments made because of university procedure. Things still work heavily by paper which could be made electronic. Some physicians tend to look down at administrative assistants.

job_title: Medical Technologist I in Chicago, IL
pros:
Leaned a lot working with pathologists
Coworkers were very friendly
Department holiday parties, bbq's, and Lab Week events were good
cons: Management is not qualified for their positions. No opportunity for growth. EXTREMELY understaffed. Micromanagement is beyond ridiculous, techs are grossly underpaid, mandatory pension contribution is steep, annual performance/cost of living increases are not guaranteed, vacation requests are based on seniority and are frequently denied due to operational needs. Training is not adequate due to departments being understaffed.

review_title: Challenging clinical experiences, many opportunities for professional growth
pros: I found the diverse work force and patient population culturally stimulating, professional staff is dedicated to quality patient care and supports one another to this end.
cons: Working within an organization as large as this can be frustrating at times as the capacity to make rapid change gets bogged down within the bureaucracy, e.g. hiring and replacing staff requires a long search and approval process

pros: Staff are friendly and competent. Dedication to improving high level of practice over all, and in creating nation wide centers in specific procedures such as bone marrow transplant for sickle cell patients.
cons: Budget is unfortunately limited in some aspects, particularly in light of Gov Rauner's refusal to approve Illinois state budget.

job_title: IT Technical Associate in Chicago, IL
pros:
- As in any state university jobs, pension, and the ability to study for free/partially paid.
- Consistently the same type of work.
cons:
- A lot of walking and traveling (involves running around the entire hospital system, clinics are offsite which involves driving)
- Tedious work (many issues are resolved easily by Active Directory policies, but they do not implement)
- Lack of training/direction (do not expect to be helped)
- Involves hospital rooms (expect to wear a hospital gown or protective coverings)

pros: Good place to learn and hone patient treatment skills on your own. Pension is a plus.
cons: Working in the Craniofacial Center is a toxic environment. Poor management. Clinicians with poor skills that refuse to learn.

pros: Fulfilling, there is plenty of room for growth... great benefits and also tuition incentives for employees and their families. Lots of opportunities within the university for networking
cons: Pay. The state has had numerous budget cuts which make raises and bonuses few and far between. My dept had a specifically high turnover rate because of this

pros: fun staff activities; prestigious reputation; great benefits; awesome people; good community involvement and opportunities for volunteering.
cons: Poor  management; horrible communication; lazy employees; very stressful environment; pension system changes; union contracts take forever to negotiate.

pros: Good employer, managers are good people and the other employees are good people
cons: Like most places execs are shady.  Get the most in regards to salary when you first start because big raises dont happen later.
